transcript.transcript: This is an oral history interview of Carolyn Kreiter-foronda on behalf of Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University Libraries. I'm Veronica Fletcher, and Robert Vay is videotaping. Thank you very much for coming today. Carolyn, thank. You for inviting me. I'm very interested in hearing about your life story. Um, usually we like to start at the very beginning and ask you to tell us about where you were born and where you grew up. Right. Um, I was born in Farmville, Virginia, and lived for a couple of months in Crewe. And then we moved to Pulaski, which is in the mountains of southwestern Virginia. I don't know if you're familiar with that location, but it's, um, maybe about 30 minutes southwest of Roanoke. Um, and from there, that long? About third grade, maybe around 1955, we moved to Richmond. My mother was ill, and we needed to get close to hospitals. And my father got a job as an assistant principal at a high school. And so we moved to a little town called Sandston, which is just a few miles outside of Richmond. Where did you go to high school? I went to the high school where my father was principal, Highland Springs High School, and am very proud of the fact that he was the big boss. He was well regarded. Were you? Did you enjoy being a student? Um, I did. I've always been someone who studies a great deal, and I love learning. And of course, I wanted to make my A's just as I did when I came here. So how did you become interested in education? Um, you know, having both parents and education. I didn't mention that my mother also was a teacher. She taught me in fifth and sixth grades. And I have an uncle who was a teacher. I have an aunt who was a teacher. I have a cousin who directs the center for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching at Virginia Tech. His sister also taught. So it's pretty much in the family. I'd say it's in my blood. And education is truly my passion. Do you remember a time when you decided that you wanted to become a teacher? Um. That's all I ever wanted to be. I do remember when we were out in the mountains of southwestern Virginia. There weren't. I didn't have, you know, a lot of young people around us. So I used to set up this little imaginary schoolhouse in our garage, and I played education. I played like I was the teacher and I was just a tiny little thing. But that's all I've ever wanted to be. You know, back when I was growing up, women didn't have the opportunities they have today. We were told in school that we could be a teacher, we could be a secretary, we could be a homemaker, or we could be a librarian. And I still recall having to write on those four topics when all that I really wanted to be was a teacher. So I guess I was fortunate, you know, given the choices. So you got your undergraduate degree at Mary Washington. Right. And then how did you hear about George Mason College? Well, what happened, actually, the two came together when I was at Mary Washington. I was president of the Student Education Association, and I was also vice president of the Student Virginia Education Association. and George Mason, which can. There were just four buildings on campus then. George Mason had just established a student education association, and I was asked to come up here and induct the officers. And I still remember there was, you know, how you you really feel the energy of a place. And I felt the energy of this location when I started teaching in Fairfax County in 1969. It was the second semester that I began taking courses through the University of Virginia Extension. Um, I wasn't really able to leave the area. I didn't have the money to go full time as a student, so I waited until George Mason started a master's in education and I enrolled. I think it was the first day that I heard about it. I drove over here and and signed up. So that's how that happened. What was that Miss Barren Campus when you first arrived. The atmosphere was very open and encouraging and I felt since this while I had been at Mary Washington, which was an all girls school, and I felt that the teachers really cared about the growth of women, and I felt that they gave us a lot of individual attention. I still remember one professor in the education department taught children's literature, and I still remember that she invited me to submit 15 of my children's poems for a publication. It was a newsletter or some publication that came out of the university, and I was so flattered by that. I had another professor who asked if I wanted to go abroad and study, and he was willing to help me work to get a fellowship. But of course, I couldn't leave my teaching job. So I was unable to do that at the time. Do you remember where your classes were held on campus? They were held in those first four buildings and then they were held in Thompson. Mhm. Um, and actually they were all over because there for a while with the education department, we were at um the school, the old Fairfax High School. I don't know if you're familiar with where that campus is. You are. Um, and that's where I took most of my classes. I remember taking children's literature there and a number of other classes, but then once the campus started building, I was here primarily and spent a lot of time in this library, as a matter of fact, studying and researching. Mhm. So you were already established in Fairfax County teaching? Yes. I was already working full time and um, at the, the only way that I could go to school was just piecemeal. So I generally took three courses every summer, and I took a course each semester. And still I was able to get through in a couple of years, which wasn't bad at all. I just doubled up in the summer, but I was so grateful to have George Mason here, and I think I spent about as much time here as I did in the school where I taught, you know, because I would leave there and come over here right after school and, and just work. And then if I needed to work in the library, I could grade papers here. I could do my research here. It worked out very well. Were there a lot of other students in your program, or was it a small program at the time? It was a very small program in the beginning, and when I eventually got to the doctoral degree, it was I think there were just maybe 10 to 12 of us who were selected that first year for the Masters of English. There were considerably more students. That was a larger program. But I also went into that program as soon as it started. You know, I just waited for Mason to add new degrees, and then I jumped in, you know, right. Right at the very beginning, because I just wanted to keep learning. Did you have a plan that you wanted to get both master's degrees, or did it just kind of evolve? Well, I always wanted a masters in English, and I had studied British literature extensively at Mary Washington. But at the time that I enrolled in the Masters of English program, I was really in need of, of of shoring up my knowledge of American literature. I was teaching American Lit at the time, so that was my major emphasis then moving into the American literature. Did you have to declare an Emphasis. Yes we did. And that was you know, it's I'm surprised that I didn't go into poetry. You know, some form of it early on. But then when I think back on it, we did not have a creative writing program that started soon after. And then, of course, I began taking classes with Peter Klappert, who is an outstanding professor. He's retiring this year, unfortunately for the students who are still here. Um, but once I got into poetry, I was always writing on my own, ever since I was a tiny little girl. But once I got into the program, I wanted to keep going. I went into the education degree because I love education, and I really wanted to learn more about methodology. I wanted to learn more about how to teach writing. Um, and I think it's important to get that background, to be able to do both. You know, I wanted to think as an educator, and yet I wanted to have the knowledge of my field as well. Where were you teaching at the time? I was teaching at West Springfield High School at the time. I started there in 1969, as I mentioned, and stayed there for a number of years in the mid 80s. I was invited to go into the area three office at that time. Fairfax County was divided into four areas, and I was invited in to teach the process approach to writing. And that was an exciting position too, because it gave me the opportunity to go out and to work with other teachers. There were days when I would go out and teach six classes, just do model teaching, and I taught K through 12 at that time and then taught some graduate courses at night. Before you even entered into the doctoral program. Um, I did a little bit, and I say that I worked through the Northern Virginia Writing project and entered that program in 1978. Um, I was also in the first group there, too. Um, and so we had the opportunity to go out and to teach as part of their writing, to learn classes. And then I also worked here in the writing center. I taught, um, students, you know, how to work on their writing. And sometimes I would be called into ESL classes to work individually with the students. That was one of my big, strong points, I think, teaching writing. Um. So we do want to discuss the Northern Virginia Writing Project. How did you hear about the program? Just being here on campus. You know, I was able to keep abreast of what the latest thing was, and I talked with Don Gallaher about it and decided that I would like to apply and did enter, as I mentioned, that first year. So I was thrilled to have that opportunity. Writers teaching, writing, um, and writers teaching teachers. Both of those concepts were exciting to me. And I'll tell you, just observing other people work and other people teach, I think makes you a better teacher. Um, it's a very humbling experience to go out into Fairfax County and to see how many outstanding teachers there are. And although I may not be able to emulate their particular style, I was able to take bits and pieces from this classroom, from that classroom, because I saw those methods work, and I wanted to add add those methods to my repertoire and to try to keep getting better. About what time? What year was this that you had started with the writing project? With the writing project? It was 1978, right? And then even after that, I stayed very much in tune with the writing project. I am asked Don Geller if he would be willing to work with me on several internships. When I moved into the Doctor of Arts in Education program. And he did. And then I had the wonderful opportunity to go into nursing homes and to try teaching creative writing there to Alzheimer's patients. And what was interesting about that is that there would be times when people were intellectualizing that they would come back into reality, but should I visit them in the room, I would see an entirely different story. I went into homeless shelters. went into the famous second homeless shelter and Mitch Schneider years ago still remember going in there and having cockroaches crawling across my shoes. And I was working with a number of people who, you know, were on the streets and who had come out of Saint Elizabeth's. I don't know if you all are familiar with Saint Ease, but that was that was a fascinating experience. And Don, you know, he he led me in different directions. He said, try this, try that. And it really gave me a lot of confidence in teaching poetry, which I'm still using today. You know, some of those skills that I learned in working with different types of learners. So the program really targeted different audiences. You would go into schools as well as the shelters and hospitals. And yes, that's a good way to put it. And it wasn't that the Doctor of Arts Program did that. It was that we were allowed to write our own programs, and I was allowed to develop my own internship. And so I used, you know, my creative put my creative thinking cap on. And I just said, this is what I want to try. You know, I have the opportunity to do this. I also worked on another program where I actually took one student and followed her learning for a period of time. And I know that Don Gallaher and Marion Moore, who sadly recently passed away, she was just outstanding in teaching research skills, um, and Chris Tice also led us quite well with the writing program. We were very, very fortunate to have those leaders. Would you describe them as being mentors? Um, yes. They were definitely Mentors. And also I credit Peter Klappert as being a mentor. Um, Peter is and I don't say this about a lot of people, but he truly is brilliant. And I just I learned so much from watching him teach seminars and from, you know, he was tough. If you wrote something that was terrible, he didn't sit there and say, well, that was wonderful, you know, but I know you can do a little bit better. I mean, he said, this is what you need to work on. And all of us worked hard. You know, I thrive on a challenge. I thrive on, um, raising the bar to see how far I can go. And my father taught me when I was a little girl. He said, don't compete with other people. For example, I could never do what you all do with oral history, but I can be as good as my capabilities allow me to be in my area. And I think that that advice has helped me tremendously, because I don't look at other poets and say, oh, that was a terrible poem. You know, I'm not really concerned so much with trying to be better than somebody or being upset if I don't get accepted to this or that or the other, but rather I say, okay, next time I'm going to strive to accomplish this. And I work that way through George Mason. What was your coursework like? Um, for the program for which? The doctorate program. For the doctorate program? Yes. Um, that that's a very good question because we sort of made things, you know, move as we were going along. I was their guinea pig, so to speak. I spent a lot of time taking the poetry writing classes. This was around the time George Mason already had a master's Um, in creative writing, but they didn't have the MFA right at that point. Um, but I took as many classes as I could, and I was right at the ground level of what was beginning to take off here at Mason. Um, Peter was wonderful at bringing in lots of visiting writers. I studied under Pulitzer Prize winners. Um, I was lucky in that one of the visiting writers who came here was I, who is a National Book Award winner and writes marvelous persona poems. I learned so much in that creative writing arena. By the same token, I was out doing the internships that I mentioned. I was also taking at that time. They were offering educational seminars. We call them weekend seminars. And so while I was learning more about writing myself, I was also learning more about how to teach writing, so that's why it's called a Doctor of Arts in Education. We were combining the two, and I took another class that I'd like to mention to you. It was a class called Ways of Knowing, and we had to. You're familiar with. That? I took that course. Did you? It's wonderful. It gives you the opportunity to see how people learn in other disciplines. And I still remember that. We had professors from all walks come in and talk with us about their fields, and that was just an extremely exciting time. Um, another course that I took in the this I'm going to jump back to the Masters of Arts. I was with Bob Nadeau, um, and he taught this fabulous course on Faulkner, and that was during the summer. And I still remember reading everything by Faulkner, and I still recall writing papers that excite me to this day. I mean, that was years ago, and I still recall the fact that Faulkner, you know, being an experimental writer, was starting to have a huge influence on my way of approaching poetry. As someone who likes to experiment with form, you know, you don't forget that kind of knowledge that you pick up. You don't forget those opportunities that set you going in a certain direction. To this day, I experiment a great deal with my writing. Well, we'll get into that a little bit later because I'm very interested. But, um, so during after you, the coursework is completed, then you have to write your dissertation. Can you tell us about how you formulated what you wanted your dissertation to be about? Yes I can. That was that was another exciting moment for me. I had the opportunity to work with another mentor, Barry Beyer, who at the time headed up the doctoral doctoral program. And Barry, as you may know, was a leading proponent of thinking skills instruction. And he was known nationally. He wrote a number of books, marvelous books that I'm sure you have here in your library on teaching thinking skills. And he got me to to thinking about what it is I was going to be doing for students minds by teaching poetry. At the same time, I was taking one of Peter Clapper's classes, and he introduced me to a book which was very influential. It was Alberta Turner's 50 Contemporary Poets. Colon The Creative Process And when Alberta Turner did was she asked poets from around the country to talk about their creative process, to talk about the revision of writing. And although she didn't include a lot of individual steps, she may have a few. And the writers would talk about, you know, their process. Um, that book just stayed with me, and I thought, you know, I spend a lot of time writing my poems. I could have at that time when we were working on typewriters, I could have as many as 100 drafts, you know. With computers, it's a lot easier just not to save your dress. You just keep going through and changing a word here and a word there. But back then, if you changed any part of the poem, you had to retype the whole thing. And I have files. I keep files on all of my poems or files that are that thick with different drafts. And so I took three poems and I went through the revision process of all three poems. And then I wrote approximately 20 to 24 page essays talking about my way of thinking as I from impetus to the completion. Again, the process approach. And then I worked with Barry, and we started talking about the thinking skills that I wanted to promote. And of course, when you're actually writing, you're working with creative thinking skills. When you are analyzing, you're honing your analytical skills. And so I developed an approach to teaching that where I'm working with building blocks, I would teach a few poems where I would focus on diction. A few poems where I would build and focus on the image which is created from the diction. I would work with symbolism. I would work with paradox. I would also, by the same token, I would work with rhythm. I would work with sound devices, assonance, consonance, alliteration. And so I wasn't asking the students to destroy a coin. You know, the deep hidden meaning. I was trying to show them how all of these structural devices would support what it is the poet was saying, you know, the structure supporting the content. And then I went out and I field tested the materials that I had developed on the analytical process. And after that, I brought it all together and wrote about what worked and what didn't work. And to this day, I'm still using those materials. I still go out and I talk about the revision process. And so I'm grateful that I, you know, was, I don't want to say forced into that kind of thinking, but that I took advantage of it. And did your committee members support Um. This process? Yes. Yes. And, you know, I'm glad you mentioned about the committee members, because at that time we had people I had somebody from history who was sitting on my committee. I had Dick Bausch, who was a fiction writer, who was sitting on my committee, and of course, Barry Beyer was on the committee. There were a number of people, and they all had to agree, um, you know, with what I was doing. And they asked some very hard questions because they were in other disciplines, and they wanted to make sure that what I was doing was sound, um, you know, theoretically and sound in a practical sense. Mhm. Um, and I worked with Dick very closely on developing some other materials during, you know, my doctoral period and some of those materials turned into articles that I've since published. Does anything stand out in your memory during either the field work or the writing process. I think what stands out most for me was the opportunity to work with Barry, because, you know, how many people get a chance to work with someone who has given that much thought to what he or she is all about? And Barry, I mean, every waking hour he devoted to thinking about thinking skills. I know that's an exaggeration, but it seemed that way and I had never gone into that much depth on a particular topic, you know. But what I learned from him is that, okay, we help our students hone those thinking skills, and then they can transfer all of those skills to the job. I mean, think about what you all are doing. You have to be extremely creative in what you do. You have to come up with the questions, for heaven's sakes. You have to do the research on the person that you're interviewing. I mean, all of those job skills you can acquire from a subject taught well, it doesn't necessarily have to be poetry. It can be any subject taught well. You learn how to think a certain way, and then you transfer those thinking skills. And Barry made me see that larger picture, and it just threw my whole emphasis on teaching in a different direction. I felt far more solid because I could rationalize everything I did in the classroom. Um, now, while you were focusing on what your particular dissertation did, you realize that you were going to become the first student at Mason to get his or her doctoral degree? You know, I had absolutely no idea. Again, I wasn't really I mean, I was tuned in to my fellow classmates, but I wasn't really tuned in to where they were. And and again, that goes back to, you know, my father's advice. Just focus on your path. Focus on your direction. And keep in mind that with the exception of one year that I took off and worked part time here, I was teaching full time. So I would leave, um, you know, whether it was here from a class or whether it was teaching, and I would go home and start studying or start grading papers. I worked till two in the morning, and then I would get up at five, and it went on like that for the five days. I would sleep in on the weekends. Um, but it was just, you know, constant focus. One thing interesting happened, though, that I would like to mention. Now that we're talking about this, I still recall a newspaper reporter coming up to me and saying, how does it feel to be a woman Who is graduating first. And I turned to him and I said, I wasn't aware that there was any difference in the intellectual capabilities of men and women. I mean, we know that we have our strengths, but that just I wasn't thinking in terms of the fact that I was a woman. That's how comfortable I had come to feel. Mary Washington had given me a lot of opportunities to be a leader. And when I got here at Mason, I loved being in a co-ed environment. I loved working with men and women because I do think, despite what I told that reporter, I do think we think differently. I do think that the way that we analyze something is going to be a little bit different because of our background of experience. But I just wanted to share that little tidbit. Did you go to the commencement ceremony? Yes I did. It was wonderful. I was very, very excited. They had a special program, um, where I was awarded my diploma, you know, separately. And that was nice. And governor Rob was there and it was drizzling and raining, I remember that, but that did not dampen our spirits. Where was it held? It was held right on the front lawn, and it was outdoors just at that time. And then what we usually did for graduation. I'm not sure if George Mason still does this, but we divided into different schools for the diploma awarding ceremony. I remember that. Well. And hopefully you took a vacation then or something like that to celebrate. You know I did. I will never forget driving down Old Keene Mill Road on a Saturday, and I had actually gone to Springfield Mall and it was the first time that I had felt that I could just take my time getting home. I wasn't rushing to go write a paper. I mean, you can imagine always being in English and also as a writer. That's all that you do. You're reading or you're writing. And it was it was an exhilarating feeling and nice to catch up on my sleep. So we'd like to talk a little bit about your career as an educator. Okay. So during your entire time here at Mason, were you teaching at West Springfield or did you switch schools? Um, well, I was at West Springfield for on and off for about 20 some years. Um, during in the mid 80s when I was. Oh, it was right after I finished my doctorate. So yes, I guess I was at West Springfield that whole time. But after I finished, I went into an area office for six years working as writing resource. And then in the early 90s I went into area two office as an English specialist for a short period of time, and then I finished my career back at West Springfield. That was like a homing pigeon, and I'm so glad that I went back to the classroom. And that was where my heart was, you know? I just loved teaching, and I had some of my most memorable experiences. Um, during those last years. When you were in the area offices, what were your responsibilities? Um, I was largely I would go out and I would teach the process approach to writing during the first stint in an area office. Um, but of course, I also worked with the other specialists in their fields, and we would develop workshops for teachers, which we would conduct after school. We developed materials. It was an exciting time, a very creative time. And also around that time, I believe that computers came into the school system. Up until that time, we'd been working with typewriters for the next stint when I was an English specialist. I also went out and did some teen teaching, but mostly I was teaching teachers. At that time, I had set up a what I call my signature course called The Teaching of the Reading and Writing of Poetry, and I taught this through George Mason with the Writing Project and also through Fairfax County, a number of teachers, when I was an English specialist and before, um, earlier had told me that they had just never been taught how to teach poetry. And, you know, I hadn't either. I was always reading poetry in my undergraduate classes, but no one ever sat down and told me how to teach it. So I realized that not only did I want to move in that direction, but other teachers did. And so I taught that course for a number of years. How would you characterize your teaching style? I would say that I really do try to reach out and meet the needs of all types of learners. I look at learning styles. Um, I will always have when I'm teaching. I have a visual component for the visual learners that may be a slide tape. It may be that I will use the blackboard a lot. I use visuals, you know, whatever they happen to be. I also use auditory components, whether it's a mini lecture, whether I'm having students listen to a CD of an of a writer reading his or her work. And then I also do a lot of hands on kinesthetic type, um, learning, working in groups, hands on activities where they may have a number of manipulatives that that the students are working with. If I'm working with younger learners and also I think I'm very, very encouraging, you know, I try to figure out what it is that someone is good at, and then I will develop that to the nth degree. If I had a student who was excellent at metaphoric thinking, I would focus on that. That's not to say that they wouldn't learn the other skills, it's just that I wanted them to feel positively directed so that they were able to at least try some of these other skills. Um, and very seldom yell. You know, I tried to earn people's respect so that I don't have to deal with a lot of discipline problems. Can you recognize that your teaching style developed or changed over time? Yes, that's a good question. I really can, and I'll tell you, it happened when I started observing other teachers. I still remember I taught right next door to Ron Axelrod, who was a teacher of the year for Fairfax County. I taught down the hall from Jill Alexander, who was a teacher of the year for Fairfax County. And my first year, I was so lucky. Jill had asked me if I would team teach an AP English course with her after school. We didn't have that as part of the curriculum and just watching her was amazing. I learned so much and there I was, a brand new teacher, you know, absorbing all of this from a master walking by Ron Axelrod's room. I would look at the way he had the desk arranged, and I would go in and try the same thing, you know, to see if it would work in my room. And when I was in the area offices, I would observe a lot of teachers. Therefore, while I was working on intervention teams where I had to go out and work with teachers who were having a lot of difficulties, and that also taught me to think in a different way. I also had to go out and observe and evaluate, you know, write evaluations. And that taught me a great deal because I had to think again. It was what Barry taught me, and to think about what they were doing and why it wasn't working. So you've taught everything from kindergartners to fellow teachers, right? How is that different? Do you approach it the same way, or is it? I think the I do approach it the same way. I think the only big difference that I see, other than, you know, you can have discipline problems, as I mentioned. I try to like I said, I try to win the respect. Sometimes you can go into a classroom. It's very difficult to grab to grab everybody when you only have an hour. But I think as I get older I'm getting a little bit better at doing that. Um, but with adults. Adults are older and wiser. You know that old adage is true. And when you are looking at somebody's writing, you're going to see adults embrace universal truths. They are going to be, um, worldly, talk about issues that are deeper in their meaning and their implications in their significance than students. Um, but of course, students are young. They're, you know, they're just learning. Um, but that's the big major difference that I see. I think we still have the same learning styles, regardless of our age. Are there any students or teaching experiences that you could recall for us? I have many, but I will tell you one in particular, or maybe two. I had a young man that a lot of teachers had given up on. In fact, he was kicked out of most of his classes his senior year, and the guidance department came and asked me if I would take him on as my student aide. So he sat with me during that that period, he was in my English 12 class. He was also in my creative writing class and the kid was brilliant. I mean, he was so smart. And when I had him as a junior, I started teaching when he was a sophomore and as a junior, I decided to recommend him for the National Council of Teachers of English award, which is really, you know, revolves around writing. You can put a composition in or a creative writing piece in, and then you also have to do a time variety. I just knew he would win, you know, I believed in him that much. And I was a couple of teachers Questioned my decision, but he won. He was outstanding and he locked down. He got a question that revolved around computers and he was a computer whiz, but he was also an outstanding writer. That's one memory that I have. Another memory deals with a young woman, and I'll mention her by name because she's just an outstanding student and is a genius. Her name is Jenny Leroy, and we still email constantly, even though she graduated a number of years ago. Jenny was so outstanding when she came into my creative writing class that I thought that maybe she wasn't doing the writing herself, but it didn't take long to realize she was not only doing the writing. She had been writing like this for ages and she went all the way. Won every national award you could possibly win. She was one of five winners in the National Scholastic Competition. She, of course, won CTE awards. She was published, already published in Virginia writing, and she graduated with highest honors when she went on to college. You know, it's that type of experience that you remember that's that's exciting. Um, do you keep in contact with a lot of your former students? I keep in contact with quite a few. And in fact, once the poet Laureateship was announced, you would be surprised how many students contacted. You know, it's so easy to stay in contact nowadays. And they found me even though I no longer live in the area. And that meant a lot to me. Um, I read here at George Mason, a Don Blair had invited me up in February, and there were so many of my former students in that audience. It was exciting and one of the young ladies that volunteered to read one, I write simultaneous poems for two voices. She came up and it was one of my former students, and we read together, and it was a nice little emotional reunion. So yes, I do keep in touch with them. You know, I never felt that with teaching that you can just let students walk out and that's it. You know, you invest so much of your energy and your time, and they invest so much that there's I think there's a real bond that you have with young people. And what types of classes did you teach? You mentioned the creative writing and the poetry. I started teaching ninth and 10th grade at West Springfield, of course, and at that time Fairfax County had what we call thematic unit. So we were able to create our own unit for a nine week period of time, and then the next nine weeks she would have another unit, another group of students, and so forth throughout the four quarters of the year. And I developed a course on science fiction. I developed, of course, a poetry course. Um, I developed courses that focused on. There was one that was called The Devil in Legend and Literature, which was very exciting. And then I moved to teaching 11th grade, and from there I moved and taught primarily seniors, and I taught advanced Placement English and creative writing at West Springfield was so good about letting me develop, um, you know, new programs I was allowed. Well, I shouldn't say allowed, but I was asked to set up a writing across the curriculum lab for the school at one point. And another point, I developed not only creative writing one class, but a creative writing two. And then I had a creative writing three in advanced class, which I don't think we had any place else in the county. So I taught, you know, the gamut when I was there and elsewhere, when I would go out and teach, I would do pretty much what the teacher wanted me to do with what he or she wanted me to focus on. Did you have any trouble grading your students? You mean with creative writing? With creative writing or poetry? You had said that you wanted to be focused on your own work, and not to judge whether another poem is good or bad. So how did that translate into, you know, being an educator and having to teach students how to write? We experimented with the Northern Virginia Writing Project with various ways of grading. We worked with rubrics. And so what I did was I used a structure called primary trait scoring. and for all of my poems or types of poems. For example, if I taught a dramatic monologue, I would take out the prime, um, traits of that type of writing, and then I would assign a certain number of points if the student accomplished that. And because I always, you know, was able to look closely at a piece of writing and figure out what was going on, I didn't have any trouble coming up with rubrics of that nature. Um, so that's the way that I graded creative writing. I also allowed students to gain peer review, and I taught them how to use the rubrics as a guide for looking at someone else's work. And I said, no, don't look beyond this for now. We're just going to look at these traits. Remember, I was using building blocks as my teaching method so I didn't have any problem. And you know, you can spot something that's a winner. Um, I could, I could tell I could tell the direction that a student was headed in. I knew which students were going to wind up being poets, which would wind up being fiction writers and which could do both. I have students who are quite good at a variety of writing types, you know, drama. I have a former student who's now in Hollywood. Oh yeah, I have a former student who just won a national competition with writing. Not to imply that I, you know, I can take the credit. It's they're so bright. I mean, they could have done that without me or without anyone else. So let's talk about your own writing style. Okay. Um, when did you start writing a lot. And what types of works did you focus on? I started writing, believe it or not, when I was four years old, my mother had me. She read constantly to me. She read wonderful books like Pilgrim's Progress when I was a tiny little girl. She read poetry books to me and had me writing, you know, being a teacher, that was a natural thing. And then she also, um, you know, would assign a lot of themes. I remember when I was in her class in fifth and sixth grade, but but I would say from the time I was a little girl, I was writing under her guidance. And when I was in, in high school, um, or actually, I was in the ninth grade, I was training to be a concert pianist, and I had a terrible experience. My piano teacher disappeared the night before I was to give a solo concert for the whole Richmond area, and I just sort of pulled into my little shell. You know how we all go through our momentary, um, you know, attacks of depression, and that was a big one for me. But my father helped me land a job working for the Richmond News Leader as a youth page correspondent, and that was exciting. And after that, um, I used to stay in my room, I remember, and I would write fiction. I wrote a couple of rather dreadful novels, which I should destroy before it's all said and done. Um, and I was, you know, relatively decent essay writer. I enjoyed that. Um, and with poetry, I was a closet poet. And I still recall, speaking of former students, brother Rick Wilson, who, uh, got his master of Arts in creative writing here, um, and has his doctorate from Catholic University and teaches at Bishop Ireton. Um, but brother Rick, he's a Franciscan brother now. Came back to West Springfield High School and he said, are you still writing? And I said, yes. And he said, and that's when he told me about Peter Klappert and got me interested in taking his classes. And from then on, I was, you know, pretty much convinced that this was the direction I wanted to take. Saying that you were a closet poet, were you apprehensive to have people read your poems? Um, not so much read, but I didn't really want to. I didn't want to put it out to the world. Um, and I don't know why. Um, I had no desire to publish. I think I was just so tuned into my teaching at that time. But once I got in the program, um, you know, I just went full speed ahead. I started sending things out right away, and that was in my early 30s when I began doing that. I mean, I had a number of things published before, but this was when I took off running with the writing. How is your writing style changed? I think my writing style has changed over the years in that I move. For one thing, I moved thematically away, but as far as style goes, I'm still experimenting. I started off experimenting a great deal with persona poems. I experiment with the typography of a poem with the way the poem appears on the page. For example, I have one poem that's called Red Poppy, where I use what we call the drop line. And the reason I do that this is based on the red poppy of Georgia O'Keeffe, is that she, you know, she blew her flowers up so that we really had to look we had to see them. We couldn't help but see that flower because that's all there. That's what there was with me on the page. I wanted to slow the reader down so that they really had to look at what I was saying, so I dropped the line. I have other poems where I experiment with the sonnet form. I have one that's called Transparent Butterfly and Jardin de las Mariposas in the garden of the butterflies, and I have the words spread out across the page. And yet it's a sonnet, and very few people even notice that which gives me great pleasure. I like to play these little games. It's a lot of fun. So I've explored with persona poems, with typography. Right now I'm working with simultaneous poems where these are poems for two voices, as I mentioned a few minutes ago, where I have three points in one, two poems are running concurrently down the page, and then you can read them vertically down the page, but you can also read horizontally across the page for the third point. And you have basically polar opposites and Themes, working in the two separate points. And when the third point. Comes together, you have a different meaning that comes across. Or at least that's the way I play with the game. How long does it take you to write? Oh, you know, I just I'm so dogged in whatever I do. I sit down and I just keep working. I mean, I can work 12 hours at a stretch without even realizing that I even eat while I'm working. But it just varies. Some poems take longer than others. I can answer that more by saying that I have innumerable drafts and I can write, you know, 10 or 12 drafts during a stretch, during a day. Um, I try to get I try to get my poems completed in several weeks. I've been told by professors, you know, put the poem aside, come back to it. But if I do that, I lose. I lose the emotional pull of the poem, and I found that just does not work for me. You know, we all think differently. We all work differently. I've had people say you need to write at the same time every day. That doesn't work for me either. You know, you put me put those restrictions on me and that drives me crazy. You know, it's just isolating. It's putting me in a little box, and I don't want to be in a box. But basically getting back to style that my style just keeps progressing and moving in different directions. And thematically, I try to move in different directions to, you know, the may I say something about art since I'm also a visual artist, you know, Picasso and Braque worked between 1910 and 1913. They they worked on Cubism, and they did their compositions during the day. And then they met at night. And we have a number of artists who work like that, you know. They'll work together and come and look at what each one has done. And therefore, you see, if you go into an art gallery, you'll say, oh, that's Picasso, when in actuality it's Braque. Mhm. Um, I find with writing that we, we constantly have to be moving ahead too. And I welcome talking with people about writing because I think it, it makes me move ahead in my thinking to see what I haven't tried yet to see where I might head. Um, so in that regard, I welcome being experimental. I welcome moving forward constantly. Well, let's since you brought it up, let's talk about you being a visual artist. Um, the sculpting and the painting. When did you get into doing that? I started painting when I was just a tiny little girl. My mother again enrolled my sister and me in art classes, but I didn't really move into it professionally until I was in my 20s, and I know it's hard to believe that I was also taking courses in art, but I was I was studying art through Fairfax County adult education programs at night. Um, I had a friend who said, you know, you just need to go in this direction, so I did. Mhm. Um, and with the sculpting, I started doing little fanciful pieces of sculpture when I was in my 30s. Uh, started doing those when I was going out into the elementary schools, and I needed something to serve as an impetus for writing. I also saw that the young children were very self-absorbed and, you know, writing about themselves. I'm not saying that's bad, but I wanted to get them out of that. So I would take in Daddy Sacks, who was a little saxophone player, Jim Bill, who was a fisherman and who was holding a laurel twig tree. Maria, who was sitting before a spinning wheel, and I would get the students to write a persona poem or a little monologue in the voice of that figure. And so that's how that's when I got into those areas. And, you know, even now I've tried to keep that art to myself like I did with the poetry, because I need some outlet. However, this past year, um, well, the past several years, um, I've been going more public with my art as well, just because people have been asking about it. So now I have to find another art that I can keep to myself. Um, do many of the themes with the different types of art work overlap? Or, you know, how is the creative process work? The the way that the creative process works for me with art is entirely experimental. At this point, I went through all of the underpinnings. You know, I learned how to draw, took courses in drawing, and then I moved. And understanding color theory, design theory. Right now, what I do is I work in several different veins. I have paintings that are on the covers of a couple of my books, and I can hold up one. This is for my first book, most of which was written while I was here at George Mason. And this is a Dragon in Flight. And basically I was influenced by Jackson Pollock a great deal. Jack the dripper? Yes, the dripper. Exactly. And except I poured paint on the surface of the canvas. And whereas Jackson Pollock used to go around and, you know, splatter his paint, he'd pour also poured some buckets of pay. I will work with the brush and move the paint around. I sometimes spray water into the paint to cause it to flow across the surface, and more recently I have been adding sand. I have been adding glass beads. I add lots of texture to the art so that, um, I'll take that one down so that I can experiment with the sense of three dimensions on a two dimension plane. Um, and, you know, I guess I'm just, you know, whatever art I undertake, I just want to see what I can come up with and where I can head when I do one of these works that I consider to be a failed product, which can happen quite frequently. I'll rip it off the stretcher strips, cut up the canvas, and I will adhere the Pieces in a more realistic, representational way to another canvas, and I have. Examples of this on my website. I have one that's called Hummingbirds in Flight. I have another that is a flowers and I just I love exploring to see, you know, where else I can hit. And I'm going to give myself a little time this summer to go into the studio and get back to business. I've been doing so much running around teaching that I just haven't had time. So were these paintings done for this specific reason of becoming the cover art for the books or just. No, it just happened that way. In fact, the publisher of Contrary Visions, Bruno Damiani, was Scripta Humanistica, had asked if I wanted to use one of my paintings on the cover, and it seemed appropriate, because the book is called Contrary Visions, and I have a lot of poems in there that come out of my background as an artist. I have dramatic monologues and the voice. One dramatic monologue in the voice of Vincent van Gogh. I have some poems that really explore the process of art, of painting, of creating. You know, I don't just look at someone else's painting and write about it all the time. I have a couple of pieces where I have indeed done that. But, you know, even with the using art as a subject matter, I try to explore for gathering light. Stacy Tuthill, who was the publisher and founder of Scott Publications, had come over to the house and she found this particular painting of gathering light. And actually I had painted it this way. But she thought that since the book was vertical, and since it looks like it's gathering light, you know light is coming into the book. She wanted me to put the book this way. If you look at it very closely, at the actual reproduction, you can see my name is there on the side. From the original. From the. Original? Yes, from the original way that I have it, while I still have it hanging the original way at home. Okay, well, so far you've mentioned quite a few artists and poets and writers that have been influential. Could you name some of your favorite poets? Yes, I'd be glad to do that. One of my all time favorite poets is Elizabeth Bishop, primarily because Elizabeth Bishop really zeroed in on her subject matter whether she was writing about an animal, a place, whatever the subject happened to be, you saw it up Closely, just as I mentioned a few minutes ago. Georgia O'Keeffe does with her painting. And, you know, I think one of our big problems in society today. I was watching while I was driving up here this morning. I was watching people rush by. I mean, going 80mph on 95. And I got to thinking, you know, why don't they just slow down and look and notice? And that really is one of the most prevalent themes in my books. And of course, I was captivated by the way that Elizabeth Bishop was able to take a subject and really hone in on it. Another favorite poet and influential poet is James Wright, who's known for his wonderful deep images and the Deep Image movement, making that wonderful magic happen right at the end of his poems. And also, James Wright's diction is very, very accessible and I like that. I think if we're going to write, we need to communicate, you know, or else why write? I know that the language poets would cringe if they heard me say that, but but still, I think when language poetry also there is a certain there is communication and we are moving ahead. Um, another poet that I absolutely love is Gwendolyn Brooks for her music and also for her agility with form. I say agility because she was able to move from one type of from one form to another very easily, and I had the good fortune to meet her. And I've modeled a lot of my, uh, a lot of my ways after Gwendolyn Brooks, you know, in that I'm trying to, as poet laureate, I'm really trying to get out there and work with the masses rather than just trying to promote myself, I want to promote other people. And then one of my all time favorite poets also is Pablo Neruda, the Spanish Nobel Prize recipient from Chile. Because Neruda moved ahead in his writing, he wrote political poetry. He wrote nature poetry. Again, his diction is very accessible. His his works are are very emotionally moving. You know, that emotional pull, um, and he he saw a head. He had a real vision with his writing and every book was different. And I, you know, I just admire that. So those are my four biggies. And also I have to mention Peter, because Peter Klappert is, you know, he works, he's in experiments, and he does something with the psychology of the mind and his poems that I have seen few other writers, you know, be successful with. And then I was influenced by the persona poems of I when she was my teacher. Can you find out about finding that you were going to finding out that you were going to be Virginia's poet laureate? Can I what? Can you describe how you found out? Yes, I was exhilarated. For one, I received a call from Don Farrar, who is the deputy secretary of the Commonwealth. She works for Kate Hanley, who's the secretary of the Commonwealth. And she said that the governor had selected me. The the whole process works like this. There's a committee that nominates a number of poets. And then those poets. That number is narrowed down by a vote of the Poetry Society of Virginia. They have over 400 members, and the top three are invited to submit a sampling of poems, a bio, and to the governor of Virginia. And Don said that the governor, in addition to liking my poems, was also taken by my being an educator and by my enthusiasm over that. And I was thrilled. I was absolutely thrilled because, again, I can combine all of my interests, you know, in promoting the arts. The prime role of the poet laureate is to disseminate information, to get out there and to let others know about arts. And I've been very fortunate to be able to work with the Virginia Commission for the Arts in trying to promote what it is that they've asked me to get out there and, and tell people about. And I've, you know, living I live about an hour and a half from Richmond. So I've been able to go to the Library of Virginia and learn a little bit about that area. But it's just it's it was a thrill to be named. Have you done a lot of traveling? I've done more traveling than I can even tell you about. It's been day after day after day of travel. Um, I have been focusing this year on the Northern Virginia DC area. I say DC because we're so close to the area, and when I do art inspired writing workshops there, we pull from Fairfax County. We pull from the Northern Virginia area. I have worked a great deal on the eastern coast. I go into places like Tappahannock where, believe it or not, we had, uh, studio nine, an art studio there filled to capacity with people from this tiny little town who wanted to know more about poetry. I mean, that was exciting. I have spent a lot of time in the Richmond schools. I have just been driving all over. Next year I'm going out to Lynchburg. I'll be going down to Virginia Tech. I'm hoping to get into the Charlottesville area. Um, I want to get out to southwestern Virginia. Um, trying to get everywhere that I possibly can. So there's been an extensive amount of driving. And who's your primary audience? Um. Everyone. Right. Again, I have worked in elementary schools. I've worked in middle schools, I've worked in high schools, and I have taught adult workshops. I've worked a great deal more than I realized I would in art settings. Mhm. Um, because, you know, as an artist, people are interested in seeing that connection. It's worked very well. Do you think that there is a regional aspect to poetry in Virginia? Um, you know, I don't know that there is one with poetry per se. I can tell you of my the book that I'm working on next is called River country, and in a couple of the poems, in one poem in particular, that is about a dead rise. Are you all familiar with the Dead Rise? It's a work boat. A boat that used to go out into the bay and into the tributaries and dredge for oysters and get, you know, just work with getting the seafood, crabbing and so forth. And for part of that one side of the coin, I am speaking in the voice of a waterman picking up on the dialect, the local color that we associate with regionalism. It's easier to do that, I think, with fiction, you know, like Mark Twain did. Um, Bret Harte, um, and I think a number of the southern writers, fiction writers have worked with regionalism. I think that there are some poets out in southwestern Western Virginia who toy around with it. Local color and try to add that to their work. But I don't see. I think it's because we have computers, and people can be influenced by writers from abroad. They can be influenced by writers from across the country. We're not quite as isolated when we're in rural areas as we used to be. So I would have to say that I haven't seen that much. Well, right now we would really enjoy listening to some of your poetry, if you don't mind. Oh no, I would love to read something to you. And speaking of regionalism, let me start off by reading a poem that is called Dragon Run. It comes out of an experience that I had. I've gotten, you know how I told you I like to move ahead? I've gotten very much interested in the environment, and I think it's important that we try to preserve our environment. Now, he'd been reading about the Dragon Run, which is a pristine watershed that is like a serpent running down, forming the headwaters of the Piankatank River, um, which borders middle Peninsula. And so I decided that I needed to go out and do a field experience. And I went out and I got in the water, um, you know, I was fishing for the little bugs, and I tried to learn more about the flora and the fauna. And when I got home, I wrote a poem which really tried to capture that experience. It's called Dragon Run knee deep in the dragon and lean in to feel the wilderness. The brisk call of dawn splashes against ash and gum sassy this liquid sun Son pursuing a cypress. Its roots lifted from the swamp like stubby knees. Stooping with a bowl in my hands, I draw from the depths muddied snails, clams, a leech snaking palustrine waters and squirming as I fish. Careful not to tear pickerel weeds or cattails, I let pliant grasses braid the pristine path. Nibble my man made boots, gurgling through the sibilant stream. Swishing like a reptile, the windless air sliced I search loblolly spy a bald eagle lifting off chiseled bones float by opiate. The thrall I teeter fall against my jaw. A damselflies flutter like a stunned doe I flail. The taste of sediment numbs my senses. I breathe in these wetlands like a wild iris. Wonderful. Thank you. Um. Another poem that came out of really observing the life around me. I seemed to like all the creatures that everyone else looks askance at. I love crows because I think they're extremely intelligent birds. I also love the osprey. The osprey builds a very messy nest, and it's fascinating to watch these intelligent creatures return year after year and raise their young. Um, this poem is called Nest Building and it was inspired by a painting called Tree of Life. Osprey by Kathleen Nofsinger. There's an epigraph from Herman Melville which reads, there are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the true method. The osprey soars through a cerulean sky scumbled with oyster pinks and whites. Industrious, he scavenges insect carcasses, sticks, seaweed, swells of twine, drops them between a dying hardwoods branches. Mellon light slides over his wide spread wings over talons, lowering twigs into the lopsided nest, shifting his weight. He shelters a jumble of crosshatched twigs while house sparrows flit in and out of leafy nooks. Back and forth they zip the hawk, oblivious to the goings on in the basement to the halo of bugs, ticks, mites, larva drawn to fish guts left over from a noon day meal back at shore. He shakes off tawny flecks of matter before gathering corn stalks to plump up his bulky home. Four feet deep this week. Deeper. Next, he boasts to himself, content to live by the river's edge where trout are plentiful, puttering packrat. He'll forage again tomorrow. His random collections tug at the soul. Call him back to this thriving creation of flutter, with wiggles and squeals lit up like spooned honey. He zeroes in to land. That's great. Thank you. And you know, I think that, um, the little creatures become a metaphor for us, you know, for the struggles that we have. Can you imagine building a nest like that and sitting on those eggs? It's something that we just take for granted, and they have to survive. We've set up a wildlife retreat at our home. We got in touch with the National Wildlife Federation and learned how to do this. And so we welcome the raccoons. We welcome all the creatures. Right now we have a number of grackles which people also don't like. We have the cowbirds which lay their eggs in other bird's nest. Um, you know, we have a little bit of everything. We have the Blue Jays, we have the wonderful wrens, we have, um, the we have deer, of course, and we have fox. We even helped raise the little fox after she got hurt. Um, so it's exciting. Do you find yourself cheating and feeding them yourself or. No. I mean, that would be wrong, right? It would be. You're absolutely right about that. And we my husband was a veterinarian for 20 years, so he's very careful about what we do and what we don't do. But no, we try to we put out food for the birds and we put that off on the edge of our property. We live on a wooded setting that borders the cove, and we put out fresh water twice daily and do just about everything we possibly can, you know, to help them. But the whole goal is just as you're implying. We want the animals to survive, you know, to be able to take care of themselves. And I think we can stymie that growth. Yeah. So do you foresee a lot of your poetry in the near future being a nature oriented? Um, right now it is. And I don't know how long that will last, because now I'm chomping at the bit to get back to writing in the voice of, um, artist. I just did a poem. In fact, Rei Berroa, who was one of the Spanish professors here, had invited me to be the master teacher over in Arlington at the Arts Centre and RT and a number of the professors, and I think some of these students worked on translating some of my poems and they translated a Frida Kahlo poem, a poem that's in her voice. And I love research. I mean, here we are sitting in a library that couldn't be a better place for us to be. You know, for somebody, all of us. We love books and we love learning in that way. And many of my poems are research based. I had to do a great deal of research on the Osprey to make sure that I got every fact right, and I wanted to use that word fish guts in a poem and make it work. You know, I like those little challenges that may not meet the eye as being challenges. I enjoy going out with Dragon Rhyme. I had a ball going out there that day. I had to understand the dragon and I have since participated in programs that the Friends of Dragon Run have sponsored to try to, uh, to help this pristine area stay pristine. Uh, you know, it's it's important that we give of our time to understand our subjects that we are trying to, um, to develop, but also when we're dealing with something like a theme of environmentalism, we want to make sure that we understand it from the grassroots. So what are your plans in the upcoming months during the remaining of your tenure? Okay. I, uh, let me tell you a little bit about what I've done so far, and then I'll tell you about the direction that I'm moving in. Last summer, I was very fortunate to meet the publisher of White Pine Press, and I just happened to be talking with him about a book giveaway program. I've always, you know, given lots of books away to students. And he said, well, it's Dennis Maloney. Dennis said, well, how would you like to for me to send you some books? I thought, oh gosh, that would be wonderful, because he had some in a warehouse and he was willing to donate to the poetry in the schools program for Virginia. Well, he sent 13 boxes of books, and I immediately started running around. I brought books up here to George Mason. I took books to Mary Washington. I donated books to William and Mary. Old Dominion University got them into some high schools. And that was one of my big programs that I launched. University of Arkansas has also since contributed books to this program. The. I had started a poetry in the schools program for the Poetry Society of Virginia back in 2001, and I've been working on that ever since. So I've been running around going into schools, which I will continue to do next year. I have also, I started in 2002, a program where, um, with the financial backing of the Poetry Society of Virginia, we have been donating $2,500 permanent endowments to universities throughout the state so that they could have what's called the College Prize. Um, the college prize is the brainchild of the Academy of American Poets. And basically 1 or 2 students in a graduate writing program will be awarded this very prestigious prize for their poetry for what they have done. Um, so I've gotten that going in four schools so far, and I'm going to universities and I'm going to continue that thrust. I have also started on my website, a spotlight page that It features poets from around the state, and I'm taking poets at different points in their career, not just poets who are widely published, but poets who show a great deal of promise in what they're doing. And I featured a number of poets who are older. I've featured, actually, I featured a number of college professors and asked the college professors if they would choose students to feature a feature. Peter Klappert and then one of his outstanding students from George Mason, um, featured a professor at Old Dominion University, Louis Gloria, and one of her students. This month, I'm featuring Ed Law, who was a past president of the Poetry Society of Virginia and who also, incidentally, co-edited this book for Virginia Poets Laureate with me. This is the latest book, and I'm giving a copy to the university Today. It features four of my predecessors. We just finished working on this instructional guide. This year it came out in December. So this has been a huge project. And um, so that gives you some idea of the direction that I have taken with being the poet laureate. I have spent hours working on this, but thoroughly enjoying it, and next year I hope to do more of the same. I also want to continue working. I want to get the River country book out that's ready, and I just need to have some time to get that, you know, find a publisher and get that out. And then I also want to continue going into the schools and working with students, but also working with adults and going into art galleries. It seems like you're as busy now as ever then. Even more so, which I didn't think was going to happen. I thought I would retire and I could, but I can't sit still, you know? I was never able to do that. I just I'm an in motion person. I can sit when I'm doing my writing. I stand when I'm painting for the most part. But other than that, I have got to be on the go, you know? I just thrive on that busyness. So you continually, you know, far into the future, still see yourself involved in these programs? Yes, for as long as I can go. I'm 60 years old now, and, you know, I can feel the wear and tear of the years. So sometimes I even have to slow down. I mean, today's a typical example. I was up at 530, you know, drove up here afterwards and going downtown to the, uh, to an art gallery to I was invited to participate in a tour with Bill Christenberry, who his works are on display at the American Art Museum. And I couldn't turn that down. I mean, you know, to walk through somebody's exhibit with the artist in here and talk about it, you know, there's going to be a poem there or a workshop. So I'm sure that I will continue finding ways to connect everything that I'm involved in. It's it just seems to be my way of thinking. Great. Well, that's all the questions we had prepared in advance. Is there anything that you feel that we haven't devoted enough attention to? No. I think you did an excellent job. I'm very impressed with your research and how much you you, you know, looked at ahead of time. You definitely knew your subject well. Okay. Thank you very much. Thank you.

lines.line: > The speaker was born in Farmville, Virginia, and moved several times during her childhood due to her mother's illness and her father's job as a high school assistant principal. Both of her parents were educators, which greatly influenced her own career path. From an early age, she was interested in education, setting up imaginary classrooms and playing the role of a teacher.

metadata.title: Early Life and Education
metadata.synopsis: The speaker was born in Farmville, Virginia, and moved several times during her childhood due to her mother's illness and her father's job as a high school assistant principal. Both of her parents were educators, which greatly influenced her own career path. From an early age, she was interested in education, setting up imaginary classrooms and playing the role of a teacher.

lines.line: # Higher Education and Introduction to George Mason

> The speaker completed her undergraduate studies at Mary Washington, where she was actively involved in student education associations. Her leadership roles led her to George Mason University, where she was invited to induct officers for a newly established student education association. This marked the beginning of her long-term association with George Mason, where she pursued further education and began her teaching career in Fairfax County.

metadata.title: Higher Education and Introduction to George Mason

lines.line: > The speaker discusses her established teaching career in Fairfax County, where she worked full-time while pursuing further education. She elaborates on her educational philosophy, emphasizing the importance of adapting teaching methods to accommodate different learning styles and the significance of continuous learning and improvement in teaching practices.

metadata.title: Teaching Career and Educational Philosophy
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses her established teaching career in Fairfax County, where she worked full-time while pursuing further education. She elaborates on her educational philosophy, emphasizing the importance of adapting teaching methods to accommodate different learning styles and the significance of continuous learning and improvement in teaching practices.

lines.line: # Involvement with the Northern Virginia Writing Project

> The speaker describes her involvement with the Northern Virginia Writing Project, which significantly influenced her teaching methods. This project allowed her to explore and implement innovative teaching strategies, particularly in teaching writing, and provided opportunities to collaborate with other educators and improve her own teaching skills.

metadata.title: Involvement with the Northern Virginia Writing Project
metadata.synopsis: The speaker describes her involvement with the Northern Virginia Writing Project, which significantly influenced her teaching methods. This project allowed her to explore and implement innovative teaching strategies, particularly in teaching writing, and provided opportunities to collaborate with other educators and improve her own teaching skills.

lines.line: > The speaker talks about her doctoral studies at George Mason University, focusing on her coursework and the process of writing her dissertation. Her dissertation explored the revision process in poetry writing and integrated her interests in education and creative writing. She also discusses the challenges and learning experiences associated with her doctoral studies.

metadata.title: Doctoral Studies and Dissertation
metadata.synopsis: The speaker talks about her doctoral studies at George Mason University, focusing on her coursework and the process of writing her dissertation. Her dissertation explored the revision process in poetry writing and integrated her interests in education and creative writing. She also discusses the challenges and learning experiences associated with her doctoral studies.

lines.line: > The speaker discusses her personal writing style, which is characterized by experimentation and a focus on various themes such as nature and art. She mentions several poets who have influenced her work, including Elizabeth Bishop and James Wright, and explains how their styles and themes have impacted her own writing.

metadata.title: Personal Writing Style and Influences
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses her personal writing style, which is characterized by experimentation and a focus on various themes such as nature and art. She mentions several poets who have influenced her work, including Elizabeth Bishop and James Wright, and explains how their styles and themes have impacted her own writing.

lines.line: # Visual Arts and Connection to Writing

> The speaker explores her involvement in visual arts, including painting and sculpting, and how these artistic endeavors connect with her writing. She discusses her creative process in both art forms and how experimenting with visual arts influences her approach to writing poetry, often incorporating visual elements into her work.

metadata.title: Visual Arts and Connection to Writing
metadata.synopsis: The speaker explores her involvement in visual arts, including painting and sculpting, and how these artistic endeavors connect with her writing. She discusses her creative process in both art forms and how experimenting with visual arts influences her approach to writing poetry, often incorporating visual elements into her work.

lines.line: > The speaker describes the moment she found out she was selected as Virginia's Poet Laureate, expressing her excitement and honor. She discusses the selection process, which involved nominations and evaluations of her work, and reflects on the significance of this role in promoting poetry and arts in Virginia.

metadata.title: Becoming Virginia's Poet Laureate
metadata.synopsis: The speaker describes the moment she found out she was selected as Virginia's Poet Laureate, expressing her excitement and honor. She discusses the selection process, which involved nominations and evaluations of her work, and reflects on the significance of this role in promoting poetry and arts in Virginia.

lines.line: > The speaker outlines her plans for the remaining months of her tenure as Virginia's Poet Laureate, which include continuing her involvement in educational programs, promoting poetry, and working on personal writing projects. She reflects on the importance of these activities in her life and expresses a desire to remain active in both educational and literary communities.

metadata.title: Future Plans and Reflections
metadata.synopsis: The speaker outlines her plans for the remaining months of her tenure as Virginia's Poet Laureate, which include continuing her involvement in educational programs, promoting poetry, and working on personal writing projects. She reflects on the importance of these activities in her life and expresses a desire to remain active in both educational and literary communities.
